title: Represent and analyze - higher freq affects C1

content.question: A sphere is attached to a vertical spring and oscillates in simple harmonic motion. The sphere’s displacement <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> from equilibrium is described by the differential equation <math alttext="the second derivative of x with respect to t equals negative C sub 1, end sub, x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>C</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mi>x</mi></math>, where <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> is the time and <math alttext="C sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>C</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is a positive constant. In a second setup with a different sphere and a different spring, the oscillation frequency is higher than in the original setup. For the second setup, how is the differential equation describing the motion different, if at all, from that of the first setup?

choices.label: A different constant greater than <math alttext="C sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>C</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is used.
A different constant less than <math alttext="C sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>C</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is used.
An additional constant is added to the right-hand side of the equation.

content.answer: A different constant greater than <math alttext="C sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>C</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is used.

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
